Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2014 08:47AM Mattsbabe wrote: Hi!  I just posted for the first time yesterday - am also waiting results, etc.  I am learning very quickly that you have to be your own health advocate...so kudos to you for taking charge!  The waiting is so difficult...just know you are not alone in the waiting game.  Best wishes and God bless you!
Posts.Title: Frustrated! cnpemt Mattsbabe

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2014 08:55PM Mattsbabe wrote: Thanks for your quick response...no, the baseline was not lost.  The Dr. just didn't send it, so I had to give them my personal copies - just frustrating because I don't feel like I have a true result until the comparison is done.  (Not sure if this is rational thinking either).  I am waiting to see if this changes the BI-RAD score due to so many changes since the last diagnostic mammo and ultrasound.  I'm probably overreacting - and have probably been reading things online that are not necessarily documented truths - so yes, fear has been building.
Posts.Title: Not usually a worrier...but...I'm so worried!!! Mattsbabe MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2014 09:57AM Mattsbabe wrote: Thanks, I have read so many helpful articles on this site!!  MellissaDallas, I Googled what you mentioned, and am not sure this applies to me.  My cysts are complex cysts, not simple cysts.  And one of them could be a solid nodule.  At the time they didn't have my comparison films - now they do - am waiting to see if it changes anything.  There have been a lot of changes since my last mammo...thanks for your suggestion!  The waiting is so difficult...trying to keep calm.  My husband wants me to get a second opinion when the final results come back and to see a specialist (besides OB/GYN), just to be on the safe side.  We shall see...
Posts.Title: Not usually a worrier...but...I'm so worried!!! Mattsbabe MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2014 10:04AM Mattsbabe wrote: Thanks, vbishop!  I try to keep reminding myself of that - but its hard to keep your mind from wandering! :) I do not have a family history of BC (except my maternal grandmother - when she was 95 - so I don't think that counts much).  Like I mentioned before - I am not usually a worrier...but sometimes you just get a "gut feeling" that something is not right...this instinct/feeling saved my unborn child 19 years ago when the doctors said everything was fine.  My husband complains about my nonchalance about things that he incessantly worries about (he's a worry wart!).  :)  Thanks again for the reminder...
Posts.Title: Not usually a worrier...but...I'm so worried!!! Mattsbabe MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Mattsbabe wrote: Hi!  I am 42 years old and very worried about my mammogram & ultrasound results.  18 months ago, I found a lump in my left breast - had a diagnostic mammogram followed by ultrasound.  The tests showed a small simple cyst in my left breast and very dense breasts (nothing in the right breast)...no worries!   A few weeks ago, at my annual "girlie" visit, I had a mammo screening- it was abnormal.  I was called back for diagnostic mammo and ultrasound due to "question of asymmetries amongst very dense tissue".  The diagnostic mammogram confirmed the asymmetry, but "very dense tissue makes it difficult to assess for possible underlying abnormality".  Hence, the ultrasound.  The ultrasound showed the following:  "Right breast survey ultrasound shows a 1.6 cm complex cyst versus solid nodule at the 10:00 position.  No additional cysts or nodules are seen elsewhere in the right breast.  Left breast survey ultrasound shows several hypoechoic foci.  The 12:00 position there is a 4mm mildly complex cyst.  In the 2:00 position there is an 8mm complex cyst.  At the 4:00 position there is a 7mm complex cyst.  There are also at least 2 axillary lymph nodes seen measuring 2.3 cm and 1.7 cm." My biggest frustration???  The report said that they didn't have comparison films and gave me a BI-RADS category #3 and told me to see them in 6 months!  My doctor's office assured me they would send all of my films/reports prior to the study (they had 2 weeks to do this).  Since they didn't, I had to take all of my personal copies to the diagnostic center yesterday afternoon.  Now it's a waiting game to see if the BI-RADS score changes.  Like I mentioned in the heading - I am usually NOT a worrier - but for some reason I am terrified!  I'm not sure if it's because I have reason to be, or if it's because a girlfriend of mine was just diagnosed.  I just feel that there have been a LOT of change in 18 months....and something has to be causing it!  Any thoughts??? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Not usually a worrier...but...I'm so worried!!! Mattsbabe MelissaDallas
